messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 68 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Nullstellensatz Size-Degree Trade-offs from Reversible Pebbling1footnote 11footnote 1A preliminary version of this work appeared in CCC 2019.

Paper Abstract: Abstract We establish an exactly tight relation between reversible pebblings of graphs and Nullstellensatz refutations of pebbling formulas, showing that a graph Gùê∫G can be reversibly pebbled in time tùë°t and space sùë†s if and only if there is a Nullstellensatz refutation of the pebbling formula over Gùê∫G in size t+1ùë°1t+1 and degree sùë†s (independently of the field in which the Nullstellensatz refutation is made). We use this correspondence to prove a number of strong size-degree trade-offs for Nullstellensatz, which to the best of our knowledge are the first such results for this proof system.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 68 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 68"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Space complexity in propositional calculus",
        "Smaller explicit superconcentrators",
        "Size-degree trade-offs for sums-of-squares and Positivstellensatz proofs",
        "Narrow proofs may be maximally long",
        "Proof complexity meets algebra",
        "High parallel complexity graphs and memory-hard functions",
        "The relative complexity of NP search problems",
        "Homogenization and the polynomial calculus",
        "Logical reversibility of computation",
        "Time/space trade-offs for reversible computation",
        "Size-space tradeoffs for resolution",
        "The relation between polynomial calculus, Sherali-Adams, and sum-of-squares proofs",
        "Lower bounds on Hilbert‚Äôs Nullstellensatz and propositional proofs",
        "Proof complexity in algebraic systems and bounded depth Frege systems with modular counting",
        "Canonical Expressions in Boolean Algebra",
        "Understanding space in proof complexity: Separations and trade-offs via substitutions",
        "Some trade-off results for polynomial calculus",
        "Good degree bounds on Nullstellensatz refutations of the induction principle",
        "Time and space bounds for reversible simulation",
        "Lower bounds on Nullstellensatz proofs via designs",
        "Short proofs are narrow‚Äîresolution made simple",
        "Using the Groebner basis algorithm to find proofs of unsatisfiability",
        "Efficient compilation of linear recursive programs",
        "Hardness of approximation in PSPACE and separation results for pebble games (Extended abstract)",
        "An observation on time-storage trade off",
        "Tight bounds for monotone switching networks via Fourier analysis",
        "Graph pebbling with many free pebbles can be difficult",
        "Extreme time-space tradeoffs for graphs with small space requirements",
        "Tight rank lower bounds for the Sherali‚ÄìAdams proof system",
        "Pebbling and proofs of work",
        "Lifting with simple gadgets and applications to circuit and proof complexity",
        "Average case lower bounds for monotone switching networks",
        "Explicit constructions of linear-sized superconcentrators",
        "Exponential lower bound for static semi-algebraic proofs",
        "Adventures in monotone complexity and TFNP",
        "The pebbling problem is complete in polynomial space",
        "On time versus space",
        "Lower bounds for the polynomial calculus and the Gr√∂bner basis algorithm",
        "Lower bounds of static Lov√°sz‚ÄìSchrijver calculus proofs for Tseitin tautologies",
        "Time and space complexity of reversible pebbling",
        "Pebbling meets coloring: Reversible pebble game on trees",
        "Expressing combinatorial problems by systems of polynomial equations and Hilbert‚Äôs Nullstellensatz",
        "Reversible space equals deterministic space",
        "Trade-offs between size and degree in polynomial calculus",
        "A note on Bennett‚Äôs time-space tradeoff for reversible computation",
        "Asymptotically tight bounds on time-space trade-offs in a pebble game",
        "Reversible simulation of irreversible computation",
        "Reversibility and adiabatic computation: Trading time and space for energy",
        "Reversible pebbling game for quantum memory management",
        "On the relative strength of pebbling and resolution",
        "Pebble games, proof complexity and time-space trade-offs",
        "New wine into old wineskins: A survey of some pebbling classics with supplemental results",
        "Comparative schematology",
        "Superconcentrators",
        "Pebbling",
        "Bounds on monotone switching networks for directed connectivity",
        "Strongly exponential lower bounds for monotone computation",
        "Lifting Nullstellensatz to monotone span programs over any field",
        "Algebraic models of computation and interpolation for algebraic proof systems",
        "Exponential lower bounds for monotone span programs",
        "Complete register allocation problems",
        "Space-time trade-offs on the FFT-algorithm",
        "Space-time tradeoffs for oblivious interger multiplications",
        "Space-time tradeoffs for linear recursion",
        "A trade-off between length and width in resolution",
        "Time-space tradeoffs for computing functions, using connectivity properties of their circuits",
        "On non-linear lower bounds in computational complexity",
        "Space-efficient reversible simulations"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 68 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Nullstellensatz Size-Degree Trade-offs from Reversible Pebbling1footnote 11footnote 1A preliminary version of this work appeared in CCC 2019., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
